If omit `--working-directory`, for example:

```shell
alacritty C:/User/
```

will lead:

```
error: unrecognized subcommand 'C:/User/'

```

And `\"` isn't standard escape character in XML, use `\"` will terminating string after `\`. That caused a error when wix processing in my test.

discussion_comments.comment_body:
So now there are so many styles of writing:
1.
```
"[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe --working-directory %v"
```
2.
```
"[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe --working-directory "%v""
```
3.
```
"[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe "--working-directory" "%v""
```
4.
```
""[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe" "--working-directory" "%v""
```

which one do you choose?

I still recommend using quotation marks, especially 4.

This can avoid many problems caused by encoding or path spaces.

discussion_comments.comment_body:
In my test, using single quotes not work:
1.
```
<RegistryValue Type="string" Value="'[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe' '--working-directory' '%v'" KeyPath="yes" />
```
But this work(single quotes outside and double quotes inside):
2.
```
<RegistryValue Type="string" Value='"[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe" "--working-directory" "%v"' KeyPath="yes" />
```
Even if the installation path set by msi has spaces (and working directory also has spaces), the following writing works:
3.
```
<RegistryValue Type="string" Value='[AlacrittyProgramFiles]alacritty.exe --working-directory %v' KeyPath="yes" />
```
This should be due to some patches in new versions of Windows. This is not guaranteed to work on older versions of Windows. 

Therefore, software such as VS Code will use quotation marks. This can be seen as a defensive programming technique.

In order to be consistent with the overall style of the project, I would like to ask you to choose a version between 2 and 3.

commented_code:
+ALACRITTY(1)
+
+# NAME
+
+Alacritty - A fast, cross-platform, OpenGL terminal emulator
+
+# SYNOPSIS
+
+Alacritty is a modern terminal emulator that comes with sensible defaults, but
+allows for extensive configuration. By integrating with other applications,
+rather than reimplementing their functionality, it manages to provide a flexible
+set of features with high performance.
+
+# FLAGS
+
+*-h, --help*
+	Prints help information
+
+*--hold*
+	Remain open after child process exits
+
+*--print-events*
+	Print all events to stdout
+
+*-q*
+	Reduces the level of verbosity (the min level is *-qq*)
+
+*--ref-test*
+	Generates ref test
+
+*-v*
+	Increases the level of verbosity (the max level is *-vvv*)
+
+*-V, --version*
+	Prints version information
+
+# OPTIONS
+
+*--class* <general> | <general>,<instance>
+	Defines the window class hint on Linux [default: Alacritty,Alacritty]
+
+	When only the general class is passed, instance will be set to the same value.
+
+	On Wayland the general class sets the `app_id`, while the instance class is ignored.
